file.content:
# skogix-hello-world plugin

a comprehensive "hello world" plugin demonstrating all component types in a claude plugin.

## what this is

this plugin showcases every component type available in the claude plugin system:

- **commands**: user-invoked slash commands
- **agents**: specialized subagents with custom context
- **skills**: model-invoked capabilities with progressive loading
- **hooks**: event-triggered automation

## structure

```
skogix/
├── .claude-plugin/
│   ├── plugin.json         # plugin metadata
│   └── marketplace.json    # local marketplace config
├── commands/
│   └── hello.md           # /hello command
├── agents/
│   └── greeter.md         # greeter agent
├── skills/
│   └── hello-world/
│       └── SKILL.md       # hello-world skill
├── hooks/
│   └── hooks.json         # event hooks
└── README.md              # this file
```

## installation

from the parent directory of this folder:

```bash
# start claude code
claude

# add this directory as a marketplace
/plugin marketplace add ./skogix

# install the plugin
/plugin install skogix-hello-world@skogix-local

# restart claude code to activate
```

## usage

### command component

```bash
/hello
```

demonstrates slash commands - user-invoked instructions.

### agent component

the greeter agent is available via the Task tool. claude will use it when appropriate, or you can explicitly request it.

### skill component

ask about plugin skills or request a demonstration:

```
show me how the hello world skill works
```

the skill activates automatically when its description matches your request.

### hook component

the hook triggers on user prompt submission and shows a brief message.

## component comparison

| component | invocation | use case |
|-----------|-----------|----------|
| **command** | `/command-name` | user explicitly runs workflows |
| **agent** | Task tool or auto | specialized context for tasks |
| **skill** | automatic | domain knowledge, progressive loading |
| **hook** | event-driven | automation, validation, notifications |

## development workflow

to modify this plugin:

1. edit component files directly
2. uninstall: `/plugin uninstall skogix-hello-world@skogix-local`
3. reinstall: `/plugin install skogix-hello-world@skogix-local`
4. restart claude code
5. test changes

## component details

### commands (commands/*.md)

- markdown files with optional YAML frontmatter
- `description` field appears in `/help`
- content provides instructions to claude
- triggered by `/filename` (without .md)

### agents (agents/*.md)

- markdown files with optional YAML frontmatter
- provide specialized context and instructions
- invoked via Task tool with subagent_type
- useful for complex, multi-step specialized tasks

### skills (skills/*/SKILL.md)

- directory-based with required SKILL.md
- YAML frontmatter: `name` and `description` (required)
- progressive loading: metadata → instructions → resources
- automatically triggered when description matches task
- can include additional files (scripts, docs, templates)

### hooks (hooks/hooks.json)

- JSON file defining event → command mappings
- available events: user-prompt-submit, file-write, etc
- commands are shell commands with access to event variables
- output appears in conversation

## next steps

- explore each component by using it
- modify components to see how changes affect behavior
- create your own plugin based on this template
- combine components to build powerful workflows

## references

- [claude code plugins docs](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/plugins)
- [plugin reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/plugins-reference)
- [skills documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/skills)
- [hooks guide](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks)

input.content:
# skogai-marketplace

a local development marketplace for skogix claude plugins.

## structure

```
skogix/
├── .claude-plugin/
│   └── marketplace.json    # marketplace definition
├── plugins/
│   ├── hello-world/        # example plugin
│   │   ├── .claude-plugin/
│   │   │   └── plugin.json
│   │   ├── commands/
│   │   ├── agents/
│   │   ├── skills/
│   │   ├── hooks/
│   │   └── README.md
│   └── [other-plugins]/    # add more plugins here
├── docs/                   # shared documentation
└── CLAUDE.md              # project instructions
```

## installation

from the parent directory of this folder:

```bash
# start claude code
claude

# add this directory as a marketplace
/plugin marketplace add ./skogix

# install a plugin
/plugin install hello-world@skogai-marketplace

# restart claude code to activate
```

## available plugins

- **hello-world**: comprehensive demonstration of all claude plugin component types (commands, agents, skills, hooks)

## adding a new plugin

1. create a new directory under `plugins/`:
   ```bash
   mkdir -p plugins/your-plugin/.claude-plugin
   ```

2. create `plugins/your-plugin/.claude-plugin/plugin.json`:
   ```json
   {
     "name": "your-plugin",
     "description": "your plugin description",
     "version": "1.0.0",
     "author": {
       "name": "your-name",
       "email": "your-email"
     }
   }
   ```

3. add your plugin components:
   - `commands/` - slash commands (*.md)
   - `agents/` - specialized subagents (*.md)
   - `skills/` - model-invoked capabilities (*/SKILL.md)
   - `hooks/` - event-triggered automation (hooks.json)

4. register in `.claude-plugin/marketplace.json`:
   ```json
   {
     "name": "your-plugin",
     "source": "./plugins/your-plugin",
     "description": "your plugin description"
   }
   ```

5. reinstall marketplace and plugin:
   ```bash
   /plugin marketplace remove skogai-marketplace
   /plugin marketplace add ./skogix
   /plugin install your-plugin@skogai-marketplace
   ```

## development workflow

1. edit plugin files in `plugins/your-plugin/`
2. uninstall plugin: `/plugin uninstall your-plugin@skogai-marketplace`
3. reinstall plugin: `/plugin install your-plugin@skogai-marketplace`
4. restart claude code
5. test changes

## references

- [claude code plugins docs](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/plugins)
- [plugin reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/plugins-reference)
- [skills documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/skills)
- [hooks guide](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks)

message.content: now is there any reason to have all these "collected" in a single folder like this?

content.thinking:
The user is asking if there's any reason to keep all plugins collected in a single folder structure like this. Let me think about this...

Looking at the current structure:
- We have a marketplace that contains multiple plugins
- Each plugin is in `plugins/*/`
- They share a single marketplace.json

The user might be questioning whether:
1. Plugins should be separate repositories instead of in one folder
2. Whether the marketplace structure is necessary
3. If there's any benefit to grouping them vs having them separate

Let me think about the plugin system works based on what I can see:
- marketplace.json defines plugins with a "source" path
- Each plugin has its own .claude-plugin/plugin.json
- Plugins are installed from a marketplace

So the question is: what's the benefit of having a single marketplace with multiple plugins vs having each plugin as its own marketplace?

Benefits of single marketplace:
- Shared documentation (docs/)
- Easier development workflow - one repo
- Can version/release together
- Shared tooling/hooks potentially

Benefits of separate plugins:
- Independent versioning
- Can install from different sources
- Cleaner separation of concerns
- Each plugin can be its own git repo

content.text:
good question. there's no technical requirement to have them in a single marketplace folder. you could structure this several ways:

## options

**1. single marketplace, multiple plugins** (current)
- all plugins share one marketplace.json
- easier to manage if plugins are related/developed together
- shared docs/tooling
- install: `hello-world@skogai-marketplace`

**2. separate marketplaces per plugin**
- each plugin dir is its own marketplace
- `plugins/hello-world/.claude-plugin/marketplace.json` points to `./`
- completely independent
- install: `/plugin marketplace add ./plugins/hello-world`

**3. flat structure - no plugins folder**
- just have `hello-world/`, `another-plugin/` at root
- each is its own marketplace
- simplest if plugins are unrelated

## what makes sense for you?

depends on your intent:
- **related plugins** (same ecosystem/theme) → single marketplace makes sense
- **unrelated plugins** → separate marketplaces or repos probably cleaner
- **experimentation/templates** → single marketplace is convenient

what's your use case? are you building multiple related plugins or just want a development setup that could hold various experiments?

content.content:
# Claude Code Plugin Structure

Based on the documentation, here's the essential structure:

## Required Components

**Mandatory file:**
- `.claude-plugin/plugin.json` — "Plugin metadata" defining the plugin's name, description, version, and author

## Optional Components

You can add any or all of these directories at the plugin root:

- **`commands/`** — "Custom slash commands" defined as markdown files
- **`agents/`** — Agent definitions for specialized functionality
- **`skills/`** — "Agent Skills" that extend Claude's capabilities via `SKILL.md` files
- **`hooks/`** — Event handlers defined in `hooks.json`
- **`.mcp.json`** — Configuration for external tool integration

## Directory Layout

```
plugin-name/
├── .claude-plugin/
│   └── plugin.json          # Required
├── commands/                 # Optional
├── agents/                   # Optional
├── skills/                   # Optional
└── hooks/                    # Optional
```

The key takeaway: only the `.claude-plugin/plugin.json` manifest is required. Everything else depends on what functionality you want to add to Claude Code.

content.content:
# Minimal Claude Plugin Structure

Based on the documentation, here's what's actually required:

## Essential Files

**Plugin manifest is mandatory.** The plugin.json file must exist at `.claude-plugin/plugin.json` and contains:

- `name` (required): unique kebab-case identifier
- `version`, `description`, `author`, `license` (metadata)

## Minimal Directory Structure

```
my-plugin/
├── .claude-plugin/
│   └── plugin.json
└── [optional component directories]
```

## Component Directories (Optional)

According to the docs, these default locations are scanned automatically if they exist:

- `commands/` — for slash command definitions
- `agents/` — for subagent markdown files  
- `skills/` — for Agent Skills with SKILL.md files
- `hooks/` — for hook configurations
- `.mcp.json` — for MCP server definitions

However, **none of these component directories are strictly required** to have a valid plugin. A plugin can exist with just the manifest.

## Key Principle

The documentation states: "Custom paths supplement default directories - they don't replace them." This means if you have no `commands/` folder, the plugin simply provides no commands. The system gracefully handles missing component directories.

**Bottom line:** Only `.claude-plugin/plugin.json` with a `name` field is technically mandatory for Claude Code to recognize and load a plugin.

content.content:
# Custom Plugin Paths Configuration

Yes, you can configure custom paths in `plugin.json`. According to the documentation:

> "Custom paths supplement default directories - they don't replace them."

You can specify custom locations for components using these fields:

- **`commands`**: string or array for additional command files/directories
- **`agents`**: string or array for additional agent files
- **`hooks`**: string or object for hook config path or inline config
- **`mcpServers`**: string or object for MCP config path or inline config

**Important caveat**: If default directories like `commands/` exist, they'll be loaded *in addition to* your custom paths. All paths must be relative to the plugin root and start with `./`.

Example:
```json
{
  "commands": ["./specialized/deploy.md"],
  "agents": "./custom-agents/"
}
```

So you have flexibility, but the default directories aren't replaced—they work alongside custom paths for comprehensive component discovery.

# Plugin Path Requirements in Claude Code

Based on the documentation, custom paths in `plugin.json` have specific constraints:

## Path Behavior Rules

All paths must be **relative to the plugin root and start with `./`**. The documentation explicitly states:

> "All paths must be relative to plugin root and start with `./`"

This means:
- **Parent directory references (`../`) are not permitted** — paths cannot escape the plugin directory
- All custom paths must be contained within the plugin root
- Paths must use the `./` prefix notation

## Syntax for Component Paths

**Commands:**
```json
"commands": "./custom/commands/special.md"
// or multiple:
"commands": ["./cmd1.md", "./cmd2.md"]
```

**Agents:**
```json
"agents": "./custom/agents/"
// or array form:
"agents": ["./custom-agents/reviewer.md"]
```

**Skills:**
```json
// Located in default skills/ directory

toolUseResult.result:
# Plugin Path Requirements in Claude Code

Based on the documentation, custom paths in `plugin.json` have specific constraints:

## Path Behavior Rules

All paths must be **relative to the plugin root and start with `./`**. The documentation explicitly states:

> "All paths must be relative to plugin root and start with `./`"

This means:
- **Parent directory references (`../`) are not permitted** — paths cannot escape the plugin directory
- All custom paths must be contained within the plugin root
- Paths must use the `./` prefix notation

## Syntax for Component Paths

**Commands:**
```json
"commands": "./custom/commands/special.md"
// or multiple:
"commands": ["./cmd1.md", "./cmd2.md"]
```

**Agents:**
```json
"agents": "./custom/agents/"
// or array form:
"agents": ["./custom-agents/reviewer.md"]
```

**Skills:**
```json
// Located in default skills/ directory
// Or referenced via custom paths with same restrictions
```

## Important Note

Custom paths **supplement default directories** rather than replace them. If a `commands/` directory exists, it loads alongside custom command paths specified in the manifest.

With symlinks:

- Edit a file thinking it's plugin-specific when it's shared
- Delete something thinking it's contained when it affects multiple plugins
- Have mysterious bugs because two plugins are trampling on shared state
- Not understand why changes to one plugin affect another

So the ".." restriction in plugin.json was probably as much about preventing user footguns as about security.

content.text:
haha exactly! that's the perfect illustration.

## the human factor

if experienced linux users still don't grok symlink semantics after *15 years*, then allowing symlinks in plugins is asking for chaos:

- "i deleted hello-world, why is test-plugin broken?"
- "i edited this skill, why did it change in three other plugins?"
- "i can't figure out where this file actually lives"
- "why does my plugin directory show 2KB but contains megabytes of stuff?"

## pwd vs realpath
- `pwd` - shows where you think you are (follows symlinks)
- `pwd -P` - shows where you physically are (resolves symlinks)
- `realpath .` - same as `pwd -P` but also works for files

the fact that this is confusing to most people proves your point: **symlinks break the principle of least surprise**.

## good UX design

even though the system runs with full privileges, it should still prevent footguns:
- enforce self-contained plugins
- make filesystem match mental model
- fail fast on weird setups
- clear error messages

allowing symlinks is technically "consistent with the trust model" but terrible UX because it creates invisible coupling that confuses everyone.
